metadata.title: Accelerated intermediate conversion through nickel doping into mesoporous Co-N/C nanopolyhedron for efficient ORR

(b) XPS survey spectrum of Co&Ni@N/C. High-resolution XPS (c) C 1s, (d) N 1s, (e) Co 2p, and (f) Ni 2p spectra of Co&Ni@N/C nanopolyhedron (gray points are raw data, and solid traces are fitted results). Fig. 2 SEM images of Co-N/C (a) and Co&Ni@N/C (b, c). SEM mapping of Co&Ni@N/C (d). Fig. 3 TEM images of (a) Co-N/C and (b) Co&Ni@N/C; high-resolution TEM images of (c) Co-N/C and (d) Co&Ni@N/C. Fig. 4 (a) Nitrogen sorption measurement for Co-N/C. (b) Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution for Co-N/C. (c) Nitrogen sorption measurement for Co&Ni@N/C. (d) BJH pore size distribution for Co&Ni@N/C. Fig. 5 Electrochemical evaluation of catalysts in alkaline media. (a) LSVs of Co-N/C, Co&Ni@N/C and commercial 20 wt% Pt/C at 1600 r min−1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH (scan rate: 10 mV s−1); (b) LSV curves of Co&Ni@N/C catalyst with various rotation rates from 400 to 3600 r min−1 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1; (c) Chronoamperometric response of Co&Ni@N/C and 20 wt% Pt/C (10 vol% methanol was added at the time of arrow) at 0.8 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) with 1600 r min−1. (d) Chronoamperometric response of Co&Ni@N/C catalyst and 20% Pt/C in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 0.8 V vs. RHE. Fig. 6 The potential-dependent in situ SERS spectra (400–2000 cm−1) on an SERS-active gold electrode coated with Co&Ni@N/C in the O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH within the potential range of 1.0 to 0.6 V. The sample surface before the electrochemical measurements are also given (labeled as initial). Fig. 7 (a) Free energy diagram for the four-electron associative ORR on Co and Co-Ni. The free energy diagram is shown at two different potentials: 0 V (left), and 1.23 V (right). The positive-shift of the band center (to near Fermi level) are shown in (b) Co-Ni slab and (c) Co slab. Scheme 1 Proposed synthetic protocol for Co&Ni@N/C nanopolyhedron. Accelerated intermediate conversion through nickel doping into mesoporous Co-N/C nanopolyhedron for efficient ORR Jianxin Mao a Peng Liu a Jiawen Li a Jianyue Yan a Shen Ye b ⁎ Wenbo Song a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun 130012 Jilin China College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China b Department of Chemistry, Graduate School of Science, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan Department of Chemistry Graduate School of Science Tohoku University Sendai 980-8577 Japan Department of Chemistry, Graduate School of Science, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Nickel & cobalt synergy in Co&Ni@N/C mesoporous nanopolyhedron accelerates intermediate conversion during ORR. Engineering non-precious metals into nitrogen-doped carbon is employed to improve electrocatalyst activity towards oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). A nickel-doped Co-N/C mesoporous nanopolyhedron is successfully evoluted from a Ni-doped ZIF-67 precursor. The Ni & Co synergistic N/C catalyst exhibits a half-wave potential of 0.895 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) with a diffusion-limiting current density of 6.1 mA cm−2 for alkaline ORR at 1600 r min−1, which is competitive to commercial Pt/C in terms of cost, methanol tolerance, and long-term stability. In situ surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) study reveals the formation and fast conversion of superoxide ion ( O 2 - ) intermediate on the catalyst surface. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrate the decrease of energy barrier for potential-determining step (O* protonation) by Co-Ni synergy as well as the reduction of adsorption energy on catalyst surface upon nickel doping. The joint results of in situ SERS study and DFT calculations suggest a favourable ORR process on nickel-doped Co-N/C. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Nickel-doped Co-N/C mesoporous nanopolyhedron Ni & Co synergy Intermediate conversion In situ SERS study 1 Introduction Electrochemical energy conversion is a topic of increasing interest. It holds great promise to meet growing energy demands and reduce environmental pollution from conventional catalysts [1,2]. High-performance and cost-efficient electrocatalysts are greatly important to energy conversion processes. The development of renewable energy technologies, such as fuel cells and metal–oxygen batteries based on the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), is dependent on the improvement of electrocatalysts [3]. In this respect, the most commonly used electrocatalyst is platinum (Pt) based noble metals [4]. However, the poor stability and scarcity of the earth's crust limit its large-scale applications [5]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop alternatives from earth-rich elements [6], such as transition metal oxides, chalcogenides, nano-carbon materials, and organic metal complex derivatives [7,8]. So far, many non-precious metallic materials have been developed for ORR electrocatalysis. Transition metal oxides/hydroxides are highly stable in ORR conditions, but low conductivity and lack of adsorption sites for oxygen species result in relative low ORR activity [9–11]. Transition metal chalcogenides, including sulfides and selenides, have been recently explored for energy conversion because of unique 2D structure [12]. For example, MoS2, CoSe2 and SnSe are reported as high-performance electrode materials for energy conversion electrocatalysis, supercapacitors and batteries [13–15]. However, extra exfoliation process leads to complicated preparation procedure and higher costs. In recent decades, various carbon-based materials are continuously developed for ORR catalysis. Great efforts have been devoted to improve the activity and stability of these materials. The state of art strategies are chemical doping and defect engineering. For chemical doping, N, P, S and B heteroatoms are found to be more effective. Especially, N-doped carbon materials (such as N-doped graphene or carbon nanotube) exhibit superior ORR activity even surpassing Pt/C catalyst [16,17]. Recent reports have shown that when cooperates with transition metal, the ORR activity of N-doped carbon materials could be further improved. Due to high ORR intrinsic activity, good conductivity and low cost, transition metal-N co-doped carbon (TM-N/C, TM = Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) materials become particularly promising in ORR catalysis [18,19]. Generally, TM-N/C materials are synthesized from complexes of transition metal salts and nitrogen-containing carbon precursors [20,21]. Zeolite imidazole salt frameworks (ZIFs) are a new class of precursors with high nitrogen content, abundant hierarchical pores and dispersed metal sites [22–27]. Unfortunately, most ZIFs-derived TM-N/C suffer from the loss of inherent porous structure during the evolution process. Very recently, Du et al. found that a high volume of mesoporous structure could be retained in a cobalt-based ZIF-67-derived carbon material [28]. Based on good accessibility to active catalytic sites and facile mass transfer capability, ORR electrocatalysis on ZIF-67-based cobalt-nitrogen-doped carbon (Co-N/C) material was firstly explored and reported by Xia et al. [29]. On the other hand, research on ORR mechanism reveals the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates on M–N/C materials. Through density functional theory (DFT) calculations, Uosaki group proposed an intermediate conversion process of *O2 toward * O 2 - on the N/C sites. Goodenough and co-workers demonstrated that both cobalt and nickel sites embedded in the carbon matrix could facilitate the adsorption of intermediate superoxide ion O 2 - . Norskov and co-workers proposed that the N–C bonds and Ni-N x sites in the N-doped carbon matrix can help to break O 2 - (ads) bonds, promoting oxygen conversion to hydroxide in the alkaline solution [30–33]. Above studies imply that cobalt and nickel sites synergistically facilitate the ORR process. Although theoretical study predicts a promotion of oxygen conversion to hydroxide on Co&Ni co-doped N/C in alkaline media, the intermediate conversion is not explored experimentally. In this concern, we report successful evolution of Co&Ni@N/C mesoporous nanopolyhedron from nickel-doped ZIF-67 precursor, as well as a pioneer work on observation of the formation and conversion of oxygen-containing intermediates in alkaline electrolyte by in situ Raman spectroelectrochemistry. To understand the possible mechanism of Ni incorporation, density functional theory (DFT) calculations on free energy diagram and band center shift were conducted. The joint results of SERS and DFT calculations reveal remarkable synergy in multiple catalytic sites, which facilitates the ORR kinetics of Co&Ni@N/C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 2-methylimidazole (HMeIM), nickel (II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), and cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. Methanol and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from Beijing Chemical Works. The Pt/C catalyst (20 wt% Pt in Vulcan XC72R carbon) was purchased from Johnson Matthey Corporation. Other chemicals were purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagent Company. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni-doped ZIF-67 Nickel-doped cobalt zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (denoted briefly as Ni-doped ZIF-67) was prepared using a modified protocol. Typically, certain amounts of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (5 mmol, 1456 mg) and NiCl2·6H2O (1.25 mmol, 297 mg) were first dissolved in methanol (45 mL), then 2-MeIM (97.44 mmol, 8000 mg) MeOH (80 mL) solution was poured into the mixed solution. The mixture was stirred for only 30 s to ensure homogenous mixing, the raw materials did not react at room temperature (the solution did not become turbid). Then the solution was quickly sealed in four Teflon-lined autoclaves (50 mL) and kept at 120 °C for 24 h. The Ni-doped ZIF-67 nanopolyhedron was separated by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with methanol for three times and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Pure ZIF-67 was synthesized using the same method without the addition of NiCl2. 2.3 Synthesis of mesoporous cobalt & nickel-nitrogen co-doped carbon nanopolyhedron (denoted as Co&Ni@N/C) The pyrolysis of Ni-doped ZIF-67 was conducted in a horizontal quartz reactor under a N2 flowing atmosphere with the heating rate of 3 °C min−1 from the room temperature to 800 °C and kept at 800 °C for 2 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the product was harvested as black powder with yields of ca. 30%. The target product, Co&Ni@N/C, was obtained by this method. To highlight the critical role of nickel doping towards the resulting nanostructure and ORR performance, pure ZIF-67 was also treated similarly (named as Co-N/C). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization Scheme 1 illustrates the synthetic procedures of Co&Ni@N/C. Ni-doped ZIF-67 was prepared using a modified protocol (see Supporting Information). Typically, certain amounts of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NiCl2·6H2O were first dissolved in methanol, then 2-methylimidazole methanol solution was poured into the mixed solution. A hydrothermal reaction at 120 °C is subsequently conducted. Next, the Ni-doped ZIF-67 was pyrolyzed in a horizontal quartz reactor under a N2 flow with a heating rate of 3 °C min−1 from the room temperature to 800 °C and kept for 2 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the target product, Co&Ni@N/C, was obtained. In addition, to highlight the critical role of nickel doping towards the resulting nanostructure and ORR performance, pure ZIF-67 was also treated similarly. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Co&Ni@N/C (Fig. 1 a) reveals that the characteristic peak for the carbon at 24.0° is absent, indicating an amorphous feature of the carbon in the material. Furthermore, Cao et al. reported that the nitrogen-doped amorphous carbon shows high ORR activity than nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon [34]. The peaks at 44.4°, 51.8°, and 76.0° can be ascribed to metallic Ni and Co (PDF card: #04-0850 and #15-0806), indicating that Co and Ni have been co-doped into the resultant material [35]. The XRD pattern of Ni-doped ZIF-67 (Fig. S1) shows that the doping of Ni has no significant effect on the crystal structure of ZIF-67. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis shows that the atomic ratios of Co, Ni, N, O, and C in Co&Ni@N/C are 4.1%, 1.2%, 4.6%, 0.9%, and 89.1%, respectively (Fig. 1b and Table S1). The XPS spectrum in the region of C 1s shows three peaks at 284.7, 285.0 and 285.4 eV (Fig. 1c), which are respectively attributed to CC, C–C and CN [36]. The XPS spectrum in the region of N 1s (Fig. 1d) indicates the presence of graphitic N (401.0 eV), pyrrolic-type N (399.5 eV) and pyridinic-type N (398.7 eV) [37]. The content of pyridinic-type N seems to be higher than that of pyrrolic-type N. The carbon matrix with a higher pyridinic-type N ratio could increase the electron-donating ability, favoring the efficient ORR with a 4e− pathway [38,39]. The XPS spectrum in the region of Co 2p (Fig. 1e) shows two peaks at 780.3 and 796.0 eV (together with two satellite peaks), corresponding to that Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 in the metallic state, respectively [40]. The two satellite peaks can be attributed to that of Co2+, indicating that partial oxidation occurs on the sample surface [26]. Approximately 20 at% of total Co were in the oxidation state, estimated from the XPS spectrum. The small amounts of cobalt in the oxidation state are expected to provide more active sites. The Ni 2p spectrum shows that the metallic Ni main peaks locate at 854.9 and 872.4 eV, together with two satellite peaks at 867.1 and 880.2 eV. The XPS result indicates that Co and Ni mainly exist in the form of zero valent metallic state. Fig. 2 and Fig. S2 show the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Co-N/C and Co&Ni@N/C. The Co-N/C displays irregular but uniform rhombic dodecahedron structure (Fig. 2a), which retains the skeleton structure of ZIF-67. The Co&Ni@N/C displays as irregular rhombic dodecahedron with a side length of 250 nm (Fig. 2b). SEM mapping analysis (Fig. 2d) reveals that all elements are uniformly distributed in the material (Table S1). The morphology and microstructure of Co-N/C and Co&Ni@N/C are characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Fig. 3 ). The Co-N/C displays irregular rhombic dodecahedron morphology (Fig. 3a), similar to the skeleton structure of ZIF-67 precursor. By contrast, numerous nanoparticles are observed on the surface and inside of each Co&Ni@N/C nanopolyhedron (Fig. 3b). High-resolution TEM observation on Co&Ni@N/C shows clear crystalline lattices of Co and carbon (Fig. 3d). While Co-N/C exhibits amorphous structure (Fig. 3c), suggesting the importance of Ni doping on Co and C crystallization. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis is also conducted on Co&Ni@N/C (Fig. S10), and the element ratio is listed in Table S2. The amount of Ni (0.05%) in the sample is very low, supporting to the absence of characteristic Ni lattice in high-resolution TEM image of Co&Ni@N/C. The Ni atoms are supposed to dope into Co lattice instead of forming crystalline Ni. The pore structure of Co-N/C and Co&Ni@N/C was studied by nitrogen isothermal adsorption/desorption measurements. The Co-N/C shows H3-type hysteresis loops (Fig. 4 a), indicating an irregular pore structure of Co-N/C nanopolyhedron. The pore sizes of Co-N/C are distributed between 100 to 500 nm (Fig. 4b), implying the presence of macropores. The adsorption and desorption curves on the Co&Ni@N/C show H2-type hysteresis loops with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of 414.24 m2 g−1 (Fig. 4c) [41]. The feature is associated with the percolation effects in highly heterogeneous pore networks. The pore size of Co&Ni@N/C (Fig. 4d) distributed between 5 and 20 nm, indicating that the nanopolyhedron is full of mesopores. The regular mesoporous nanopolyhedron structure is considered to expose abundant active sites with high accessibility for catalysis. Facilitated mass transport/gas diffusion, together with highly active sites, is expected to have a high binding affinity to several active oxygen intermediate species in the electrolyte, which may endow Co&Ni@N/C with efficient ORR catalytic activity. 3.2 Electrocatalysis characterization The ORR activities of these catalysts, Co&Ni@N/C, Co-N/C, and commercially available 20 wt% Pt/C, deposited on the glassy carbon (see Supporting Information), have been evaluated in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) using the rotating disk electrode (RDE) technique. Each sample has been fabricated onto the substrate surface with an identical mass. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the Co&Ni@N/C exhibits an onset potential of 0.990 V and a half-wave potential of 0.895 V for the ORR process. The half-wave potential of the Co&Ni@N/C is 25 and 32 mV more positive than those of the pristine Co-N/C and 20 wt% Pt/C. Notably, the ORR limiting current density of Co&Ni@N/C at 0.80 V is 6.12 mA cm−2 (1600 r min−1), higher than that observed on the Co-N/C and 20 wt% Pt/C. Based on the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) relation, the electron transfer number for the ORR on the Co&Ni@N/C catalyst surface was estimated as 4.1 at the diffusion-controlled potential region (Fig. S4). This indicates a four-electron ORR process occurring on the Co&Ni@N/C catalyst surface, similar to the commercial Pt/C catalyst in the same alkaline solution. For practical applications in the practical fuel cell systems, the resistance of the catalyst for the crossover of organic fuel molecules from the anode side (such as methanol) should also be taken into consideration. Fig. 5(c and d) show the methanol tolerance and durability of Co&Ni@N/C evaluated by chronoamperometric measurements. The cathodic current due to the ORR on the commercially available 20 wt% Pt/C at 0.8 V immediately changes to an anodic one immediately after the methanol introduction. The anodic current should be attributed to the oxidation of methanol on the Pt surface. In contrast, a large cathodic current on the Co&Ni@N/C at the same potential keeps flowing, indicating high tolerance to methanol. The durability of the catalyst in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte shows the total current attenuation for the Co&Ni@N/C is 6.8% in a period of 30,000 s. better than that of the 20 wt% Pt/C under the same conditions (Fig. 5d and Fig. S6). The improved electrocatalytic durability should be ascribed to the unique 3D porous structure of Co&Ni@N/C, which refrained from the destruction of the active center of material during the catalytic processes and therefore maintained a high catalytic activity. 3.3 In situ SERS study for ORR mechanism To understand the ORR mechanism, in situ SERS study has been performed to probe the reaction intermediates on the electrocatalyst surface [42–44]. The SERS-active substrate was prepared by sputtering gold onto a stainless substrate [45,46]. The sputtered gold substrate shows a significant Raman enhancement effect while itself does not show any characteristic SERS peak during the ORR in the solution (Fig. S7). However, when a thin catalyst layer was deposited on the gold surface, several SERS peaks were observed during the ORR (Fig. 6 ). These are attributed to the species formed on the catalyst surface, inducing the Raman enhancement from the SERS-active gold substrate. Fig. 6(a) shows the in situ SERS spectra of Co-N/C during the ORR. A new peak appears when the potential becomes more negative than 0.8 V. This peak can be attributed to υ Co-O2 according to Shibahara’s work [47–49]. This indicates that the Co-active center starts to adsorb a large amount of oxygen at this potential, thus initiating the process of ORR. At around 550 cm−1, a broad peak appears under a potential of 1–0.85 V. According to previous report, this peak is the characteristics of CoO(OH) produced through the oxidation of Co species [50]. This peak disappears with the increase of overpotential, which may relate with the reduction of CoO(OH) species at lower potential. The study of the catalytic mechanism on Co-N/C is helpful to understand the ORR process on the surface of Co&Ni@N/C. Fig. 6(b) shows in situ SERS spectra observed on the Co&Ni@N/C surface during the ORR process in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated by oxygen. Two broad peaks were observed around 1350 and 1580 cm−1, which can be assigned to D-band and G-band from carbon materials in the catalyst, respectively. As the potential became more negative than 0.85 V, two peaks appeared at 490 and 1110 cm−1. The sharp peak at 490 cm−1 can also be attributed to υ Co-O2, as indicated in Shibahara’s work. The appearance of this peak implies that the Co-active centers interact with oxygen, thus the ORR process is initiated. The peaks of CoO(OH) are absent in the Raman spectra of Co&Ni@N/C, which proves that the oxidation of Co species in Co&Ni@N/C is prevented. The broader peak at 1110 cm−1 can be assigned to the O–O stretching of O 2 - intermediate adsorbed on the catalyst surface during the ORR. While, this peak is not observed on Co-N/C. The difference between the O 2 - peaks for Co&Ni@N/C and Co-N/C relies on the formation kinetics of O 2 - intermediate on each catalyst surface. The appearance and disappearance of such peak reflects the accumulated amount of O 2 - species. On the surface of Co@N/C, the kinetics of O2 adsorption and conversion is relatively slow, thus less O 2 - intermediate is formed and the 1110 cm−1 peaks cannot be observed. On the other hand, the O 2 - peak (1110 cm−1) begins to appear at +0.85 V on Co&Ni@N/C, originating from the fast formation and accumulation of O 2 - intermediate on the catalyst surface. A similar SERS peak (but with a slightly higher frequency around 1150 cm−1) has been observed on the Pt single crystal electrode surfaces during the ORR, indicating a similar reaction intermediate was also found on the Co&Ni@N/C catalyst surface [51]. By comparing these in situ SERS results, the potential required for the initiation of the ORR process on the Co&Ni@N/C surface (+0.85 V) seems to be more positive than those of Pt(111) (+0.75 V) and Pt(110)/Pt(100) electrodes (+0.65 V). With the increase of overpotential, the O 2 - peak becomes weaker. It almost disappears at ∼0.6 V, since the conversion kinetics is facilitated at high overpotential and the O 2 - species are therefore consumed significantly. A deeper understanding of ORR mechanism and active sites needs more experimental and theoretical works. To further reveal the adsorption behaviour of related active sites, in situ SERS study on N/C and Ni-N/C were performed. The in situ SERS spectra of N/C are shown in Fig. S11(a). The characteristic D-band and G-band of carbon locate at 1300 and 1600 cm−1, respectively. With negative shift of the applied potential to 0.85 V, a peak at 1060 cm−1 starts to appear. According to related research, this peak can be attributed to *OH intermediate [52]. *OH is a highly active intermediate that can be reduced easily. The accumulation of *OH on N/C suggests that N-doped C has certain ORR activity. However, the peak of *OH cannot be found in the spectra of Co-N/C and Co&Ni@N/C (Fig. 6b), indicating a different mechanism of N/C with Co-containing catalysts. Different type of active site corresponds to different O-containing intermediate adsorption behavior. The in situ SERS spectra of Ni-N/C are shown in Fig. S11(b). The I D/I G is obvious lower than N/C, indicating improved carbon crystallization upon Ni doping. Similarly, the peak of *OH appears in the SERS spectra of Ni-N/C, revealing that the ORR process on Ni-N/C is similar to N/C. It is worth noticing that the onset potential of *OH peak on Ni-N/C (1 V) is higher than that on N/C (0.85 V), indicating favorable formation of *OH on Ni-N/C compared with N/C. Besides, another peak at 497 cm−1 appears on Ni-N/C from 0.8 V, which can be attributed to Ni–O bond of Ni oxides [53]. The peak of O 2 - observed at 1110 cm−1 on Co&Ni@N/C is not found in the spectra of N/C and Ni-N/C. This result indicates that the ORR process on Co sites is different with other sites. 3.4 DFT calculations Theoretical calculations were performed to study the effect of nickel incorporation on ORR. Fig. 7 (a) compiles the full thermodynamic free energy diagrams for Co-Ni slab and pure Co slab. The free energy barrier of the Co-Ni slab (0.65 eV) is much lower than that of the pure Co slab (0.74 eV). The result demonstrates that the potential-determining step (PDS) of ORR is the protonation of O (*O→*OH), which is an intermediate process between adsorbed O 2 - to OH−, corroborating the conclusion of in situ Raman study. Here, the strong synergy between the two metals in Co-Ni active site generates a lowered energetic uphill process for O* protonation. As a result, the O 2 - intermediate can be transformed quickly on Co&Ni@N/C, leading to favorable ORR kinetics. The d-band center describes the adsorbate-metal interaction. The positive-shift of d-band center (near Fermi level) represents the reduction of adsorption energy on catalyst surface. As can be seen from Fig. 7(b and c), the d-band center of the Co-Ni slab (−3.49 eV) is more positive than pure Co slab (−3.72 eV). Ni doping moves the d-band center close to Fermi energy and thus optimizes the intermediate adsorption on Co&Ni@N/C, resulting in facile ORR kinetics. 4 Conclusions In summary, a Ni & Co synergy approach is proposed to manipulate active sites and electronic states in N-doped carbon material for ORR catalysis. Successful evolution of Co&Ni@N/C mesoporous dodecahedron from Ni-doped ZIF-67 precursor is accomplished, and the resultant material exhibits high ORR activity surpassing most state of art materials. Fast conversion of superoxide ion ( O 2 - ) intermediate to OH− on Co&Ni@N/C is observed by in situ SERS spectroelectrochemistry. The decrease of energy barrier and optimization of electron density by Ni & Co synergy are supposed by DFT calculations. This work highlights the importance of Ni doping on the facilitation of ORR kinetics. The discovery of Ni & Co synergistic catalysis would be beneficial for understanding related reaction mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Engineering non-precious metals into nitrogen-doped carbon is employed to improve electrocatalyst activity towards oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). A nickel-doped Co-N/C mesoporous nanopolyhedron is successfully evoluted from a Ni-doped ZIF-67 precursor. The Ni & Co synergistic N/C catalyst exhibits a half-wave potential of 0.895 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) with a diffusion-limiting current density of 6.1 mA cm−2 for alkaline ORR at 1600 r min−1, which is competitive to commercial Pt/C in terms of cost, methanol tolerance, and long-term stability. In situ surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) study reveals the formation and fast conversion of superoxide ion ( O 2 - ) intermediate on the catalyst surface. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrate the decrease of energy barrier for potential-determining step (O* protonation) by Co-Ni synergy as well as the reduction of adsorption energy on catalyst surface upon nickel doping. The joint results of in situ SERS study and DFT calculations suggest a favourable ORR process on nickel-doped Co-N/C.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by ELSEVIER B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Accelerated intermediate conversion through nickel doping into mesoporous Co-N/C nanopolyhedron for efficient ORR
